New York University/Statistics and Data Analysis                                 Stern  School of Business   Regression and Forecasting Models      STAT-UB.0003.001 and  STAT-UB.0003.002 (also C22.0003)      Professor: William Greene, Departments of  Economics and IOMS           BS Ohio State University, 1972 (Operations Research); MA  Wisconsin, 1974 (Economics); PhD Wisconsin, 1976 (Econometrics); History:  Cornell 1976-1982; Real world, 1982-1983; Return to ivory tower at Stern (then  GBA) NYU, 1983-2008; Toyota Motor Corp Professor, 2007-. Publications: Articles  - see vita on home page ; Books: Modeling Ordered Choices ,  2010, Econometric Analysis , 7 th Ed   (2011); Applied Choice Analysis (2006);  Software, NLOGIT ( www.nlogit.com ) , Editor in Chief, Foundations and Trends in Econometrics . Editor in Chief, Journal of Productivity Analysis ,  Associate Editor, Journal of Economic  Education, Journal of Choice Modeling . Research interests: econometric  methodology, discrete choice modeling, efficiency and productivity analysis,  health economics, transportation, nonlinear estimation, entertainment and  media.        Office: MEC 7-90, Ph. 998-0876, Fax. 995-4218         e-mail: wgreene@stern.nyu.edu            Home Page: http://people.stern.nyu.edu/wgreene           Abstract           This course will introduce students to the ideas of  correlation and linear regression. Linear regression is a ( the ) fundamental statistical technique used in business, economics  and all social sciences for understanding relationships among variables and for  forecasting observed outcomes.           Prerequisites      I will assume that students are  familiar with routine algebra, exponents and logarithms as well as graphical  tools such as the slope and intercept of a straight line. Algebra will be used  freely throughout the course. We may have a rare occasion to use a derivative,  but the use of calculus will be sparing at most. Students are also assumed to  have had a basic statistics course that covered simple descriptive statistics,  some distribution theory including the normal distribution, and basic inference  up to testing a hypothesis about a mean.            Course Requirements and  Course Grades                 All examinations are open book and open notes, but closed  telephone, closed PDA, closed iPhone, closed iPad, closed Droid, closed  Blackberry, closed Galaxy (whatever), closed laptop. Do bring a hand calculator to both exams.                 Honor Code:  Of course .             Course Materials               *   The   required text for this course is: Statistics for Business and  Economics, Second Custom NYU Edition, McClave, Benson and Sincich, Pearson,  2011.            *   The software for the course will  be Minitab, Release 16. Version 16 is available from the Professional Bookstore  for about $100, but you can rent a copy for about $30 for the semester from the  website, http://kivuto.com (Minitab also runs  on the Stern server in Stern Apps.)      Other Stuff       *   Please  remember to turn off your cell phone before you come to class.      *   Please  try to arrive early. Late entrances are disruptive.      *   As a general rule, laptops and other devices  are an annoyance during class, particularly when you are checking your email,  doing whatever you do on Facebook, tweeting, watching YouTube videos or playing  Angry Birds while others are studying statistics. If you absolutely must use  your laptop to take notes, please be respectful of the interests of your  colleagues and the sensibilities of your professor.       Course Outline  and Schedule       Session 1: Basic Linear  Regression Model.    Reading: Text Sections 10.1, 10.2    Materials: Introduction ( Slides )   Slides  for this session - Notes 1: Linear Regression .      Session 2: Statistical Inference  in the Linear Model.    Reading: Text Sections 10.3, 10.4    Materials:  Slides for this session - Notes 2: Inference      Session 3: Correlation and Fit  of the Model to the Data.    Reading: Text Section 10.5    Materials: Slides for this session - Notes 3: Model Ft  and Correlation      Session 4: Estimation and Prediction    Reading: Text Sections 10.6, 10.7     Materials: Slides for this session - Notes 4:  Prediction      Session 5: Elasticities,  Coefficients, Residual Analysis      Reading: Class Notes    Materials: Slides  for this session - Notes 5: Elasticity and Functional Form      Session 6: Multiple Regression    Reading: Text Section 11.1      Materials: Slides for  this session - Notes 6: Multiple Regression      Session 7: Inference in the  Multiple Regression Model    Reading: Text, Sections 11.2, 11.3, 11.9    Materials: Slides  for this session - Notes 7: Multiple Regression Inference      Session 8: Multicollinearity,  Prediction    Reading: Text Sections 11.4, 11.12   Materials: Slides  for this session - Notes 8: Estimation and Prediction, Multicollinearity      Session 9: Multiple Regression  Model Building   Reading: Text Sections 11.5-11.8    Materials: Slides for this session - Notes 9  Model Building      Session 10: Qualitative Data   Reading: Class Notes    Materials: Slides for this  session - Notes 10: Qualitative Data              Individual Problem Sets and Assignments       Students may work with their colleagues on these homework assignments and  submit your assignment as a group. (Groups may have no more than four  students.). All data sets for the assignments are linked below. (The mpj  format will upload automatically into Minitab. The csv, xls or xlsx file will  upload directly into Excel.) You can left click to open the mpj file in  Minitab, or right click it to download it to your own computer.       Assignment 1. Problem set 1  Problem set 1 solutions   Data sets: ( Jersey  Banks,mpj ) ( Jersey  Banks,xlsx ) ( Movie  Buzz,mpj ) ( Movie  Buzz,xlsx )      Assignment 2. Problem set 2  Problem set 2 solutions   Data sets: ( Happiness.mtp )  ( Happiness,csv )  ( Happiness.xlsx )  ( Monet.mtp )  ( Monet,csv )  ( Monet.xlsx )      Assignment 3. Problem set 3  Problem set 3 solutions    Data sets: ( House  Prices.mtp ) ( House  Prices,csv ) ( House  Prices.xlsx ) ( Clocks.mtp )  ( Clocks,csv )   ( Clocks.xlsx )      Assignment 4. Problem set 4  Problem set 4 solutions     Data sets: ( Health  Data.mtp ) ( Health  Care,csv ) ( Health  Care.xlsx )      Assignment 5. Problem set 5  Problem set 5 solutions    Data sets: ( Health  Data.mtp ) ( Health  Care,csv ) ( Health  Care.xlsx )      Model  Development Project       Notes on the model development project   Data for Model Development ( Minitab ) ( Excel )      Midterm with Solutions ( Midterm-1-solutions.pdf )       Sample Final Exam Questions ( miscellaneous  questions )       Other course  with more exams, some with solutions

New York University/Statistics and Data Analysis                                 Stern  School of Business   Regression and Forecasting Models      STAT-UB.0003.001 and  STAT-UB.0003.002 (also C22.0003)      Professor: William Greene, Departments of  Economics and IOMS           BS Ohio State University, 1972 (Operations Research); MA  Wisconsin, 1974 (Economics); PhD Wisconsin, 1976 (Econometrics); History:  Cornell 1976-1982; Real world, 1982-1983; Return to ivory tower at Stern (then  GBA) NYU, 1983-2008; Toyota Motor Corp Professor, 2007-. Publications: Articles  - see vita on home page ; Books: Modeling Ordered Choices ,  2010, Econometric Analysis , 7 th Ed   (2011); Applied Choice Analysis (2006);  Software, NLOGIT ( www.nlogit.com ) , Editor in Chief, Foundations and Trends in Econometrics . Editor in Chief, Journal of Productivity Analysis ,  Associate Editor, Journal of Economic  Education, Journal of Choice Modeling . Research interests: econometric  methodology, discrete choice modeling, efficiency and productivity analysis,  health economics, transportation, nonlinear estimation, entertainment and  media.        Office: MEC 7-90, Ph. 998-0876, Fax. 995-4218         e-mail: wgreene@stern.nyu.edu            Home Page: http://people.stern.nyu.edu/wgreene           Abstract           This course will introduce students to the ideas of  correlation and linear regression. Linear regression is a ( the ) fundamental statistical technique used in business, economics  and all social sciences for understanding relationships among variables and for  forecasting observed outcomes.           Prerequisites      I will assume that students are  familiar with routine algebra, exponents and logarithms as well as graphical  tools such as the slope and intercept of a straight line. Algebra will be used  freely throughout the course. We may have a rare occasion to use a derivative,  but the use of calculus will be sparing at most. Students are also assumed to  have had a basic statistics course that covered simple descriptive statistics,  some distribution theory including the normal distribution, and basic inference  up to testing a hypothesis about a mean.            Course Requirements and  Course Grades                 All examinations are open book and open notes, but closed  telephone, closed PDA, closed iPhone, closed iPad, closed Droid, closed  Blackberry, closed Galaxy (whatever), closed laptop. Do bring a hand calculator to both exams.                 Honor Code:  Of course .             Course Materials               *   The   required text for this course is: Statistics for Business and  Economics, Second Custom NYU Edition, McClave, Benson and Sincich, Pearson,  2011.            *   The software for the course will  be Minitab, Release 16. Version 16 is available from the Professional Bookstore  for about $100, but you can rent a copy for about $30 for the semester from the  website, http://kivuto.com (Minitab also runs  on the Stern server in Stern Apps.)      Other Stuff       *   Please  remember to turn off your cell phone before you come to class.      *   Please  try to arrive early. Late entrances are disruptive.      *   As a general rule, laptops and other devices  are an annoyance during class, particularly when you are checking your email,  doing whatever you do on Facebook, tweeting, watching YouTube videos or playing  Angry Birds while others are studying statistics. If you absolutely must use  your laptop to take notes, please be respectful of the interests of your  colleagues and the sensibilities of your professor.       Course Outline  and Schedule       Session 1: Basic Linear  Regression Model.    Reading: Text Sections 10.1, 10.2    Materials: Introduction ( Slides )   Slides  for this session - Notes 1: Linear Regression .      Session 2: Statistical Inference  in the Linear Model.    Reading: Text Sections 10.3, 10.4    Materials:  Slides for this session - Notes 2: Inference      Session 3: Correlation and Fit  of the Model to the Data.    Reading: Text Section 10.5    Materials: Slides for this session - Notes 3: Model Ft  and Correlation      Session 4: Estimation and Prediction    Reading: Text Sections 10.6, 10.7     Materials: Slides for this session - Notes 4:  Prediction      Session 5: Elasticities,  Coefficients, Residual Analysis      Reading: Class Notes    Materials: Slides  for this session - Notes 5: Elasticity and Functional Form      Session 6: Multiple Regression    Reading: Text Section 11.1      Materials: Slides for  this session - Notes 6: Multiple Regression      Session 7: Inference in the  Multiple Regression Model    Reading: Text, Sections 11.2, 11.3, 11.9    Materials: Slides  for this session - Notes 7: Multiple Regression Inference      Session 8: Multicollinearity,  Prediction    Reading: Text Sections 11.4, 11.12   Materials: Slides  for this session - Notes 8: Estimation and Prediction, Multicollinearity      Session 9: Multiple Regression  Model Building   Reading: Text Sections 11.5-11.8    Materials: Slides for this session - Notes 9  Model Building      Session 10: Qualitative Data   Reading: Class Notes    Materials: Slides for this  session - Notes 10: Qualitative Data              Individual Problem Sets and Assignments       Students may work with their colleagues on these homework assignments and  submit your assignment as a group. (Groups may have no more than four  students.). All data sets for the assignments are linked below. (The mpj  format will upload automatically into Minitab. The csv, xls or xlsx file will  upload directly into Excel.) You can left click to open the mpj file in  Minitab, or right click it to download it to your own computer.       Assignment 1. -0.67         Telecommunications 1,499.50 -21.78         Utilities 190.81 -6.42         Financials 387.42 +2.93         Technology 74.42 -0.77                                The Volatility Institute (V-Lab) provides real time measurement, modeling and forecasting of financial volatility, correlations and risk for a wide spectrum of assets. V-Lab blends together both classic models as well as some of the latest advances proposed in the financial econometrics literature. The aim of the website is to provide real time evidence on market dynamics for researchers, regulators, and practitioners.     V-Lab is currently running 83,513 analyses on 16,895 datasets producing a total of 140,285 series each day!    Monitoring Risk with V-Lab: Professor Rob Engle's video lecture on using V-Lab to monitor riskat the Becker Friedman Institute    An Introduction to Financial Volatility: Professor Rob Engle's video lectures on the Financial Times     V-Lab Related Documents      Prof. Rob Engle discusses recent market volatility with Fox News Prof. Rob Engle is interviewed about the financial services industry Dynamic Conditional Beta Engle(2014) AEA Paper - Capital Shortfall: A New Approach to Ranking and Regulating Systemic Risks Acharya, Engle, and Richardson(2012)                    What's in V-Lab?
